Title: The Long Dark Tea-Time of the Soul (Dirk Gently, #2)
Author: Douglas Adams
My Review:
Very well writted, very Douglas Adams. NOT his best.

The story takes the great charachter of Dirk Gently on an adventure about Norse gods and men. While the writing is very good and the plot has that quality of "interconnectedness of all things" to it - the ending feels like a collapsing house of cards. as if all the suspense and build-up of clues and hints suddenly falls apart and the story closes feebly... or maybe I just didn't get it. It definitely left me feeling a bit cheated out of something very clever.

All in all - a really fun read, with a slightly disappointing ending.

Title: Blind Faith
Author: Ben Elton
My Review:
Meh...
It was a fun novel. But Elton can be much better. Not nearly as biting as The First Casualty or High Society, nor as mind-boggling as Past Mortem and Time and Time again.

You kinda get the whole story pretty quick. The twists near the end are nice but... meh

The back story is good for about a third of the book, then it becomes either repetetive or inconsistent.

So... I had fun but won't remember any of it in a month. A bit like the world Elton describes. Meh

Title: Thinking, Fast and Slow
Author: Daniel Kahneman
My Review: This was really hard to rate.

Title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (Harry Potter, #5)
Author: J.K. Rowling

Title: The Godfather (The Godfather, #1)
Author: Mario Puzo
My Review:
There are many reviews, but here's a thought.
I read this book as a teenager - and loved it.
I re-read it now, as a husband and father - and I love it much more

Even though the female roles are quite flat (which I didn't realize as a teen), the family aspect is huge. It is much more about family than about the mafia.

Title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy, #1)
Author: Douglas Adams
My Review: Even for the nth time - still laugh out loud funny

Title: Heroes: Mortals and Monsters, Quests and Adventures (Stephen Fry's Great Mythology, #2)
Author: Stephen Fry

Title: The Two Towers (The Lord of the Rings, #2)
Author: J.R.R. Tolkien

Title: הרצל אמר
Author: Yoav Avni
My Review:
איזה ספר כיפי. כתוב טוב, המשחק בין השפות נהדר וכל הקונספט מרתק.
גמעתי את הספר תוך שבוע בערך והביקורת העיקרית (שמונעת ממנו ציון 5 כוכבים) היא שהסופר רץ מהר מדי. הספר כתוב נהדר, אבל נראה שהיה חשוב לסופר להסביר מה היו אם על כל כך הרבה נושאים: צבא, ישראל, קיבוצים, ערבים, יהודים, דתיים, פלסטין... שלכל תשובה אין מספיק מקום להתעמק. והפרטים הנפלאים נותנים רק הצצה, כשאני רציתי מבט מלא ומעמיק.

אבל אולי זה מה שטוב בו.
4 כוכבים.

Title: Mother Night
Author: Kurt Vonnegut Jr.
My Review:
It's really 3.5 stars.
It was fun. Briliantly written,laugh-out-loud funny and quirky like a pig ballet.

But... it was short and flat. The plot seemed to have been drawn up ad-lib without planning - leading to a simplistic story with strange twists that felt fake. Like making up a story for a child and getting stuck.

So - great "weekend at the beach" book. But not as powerful/memorable as Slaughterhause 5 or some of the other works by Vonnegut

Favourite quote:
"All right, old man - tell me what to live for," she said. "Tell me what you live for, so I can live for it, too - here or ten thousand kilometers from here! Tell me why you want to go on being alive, so I can go on wanting to be alive, too!"

Title: The Book Thief
Author: Markus Zusak
My Review:
It is not often I cry when reading.
I cried my heart out.

As a Jew, living in Germany in 2021, I was really shaken by how intimate and truthful this book felt. Giving me a look into the depth of German life under Hitler. Not for Jews, that I heard often. But for the "small town" Germans.

Heartbreaking. Masterful

Title: The Hobbit, or There and Back Again
Author: J.R.R. Tolkien

Title: Foundation's Edge (Foundation #4)
Author: Isaac Asimov
My Review: Nice, but felt like Asimov was squeezing just too much from the "mentalics" lemon.

Title: 3001: The Final Odyssey (Space Odyssey, #4)
Author: Arthur C. Clarke
My Review:
Old. The writing here was just... old.
None of the magic was left for the final installment of the Odyssey saga.

Clarke's flair for describing technology was gone - as he couldn't describe anything in great detail: 1000 years in the future.

Also, the idea of a Utopian world seemed fake and unimaginative: very unlike Clarke who caught the political tensions of science very well in previous books.

Generally, it felt to me like reading Jules Verne - slow and overly descriptive. A major step down from the fast, nerve wracking and mind expanding style of 2001.

Title: The Secret Pilgrim
Author: John le Carré
My Review:
This is a collection of short stories by Le Carre, strung together under the pretext of inviting George Smiley to talk to spy-school students.
The stories are very "Le Carre", with his long winded descriptions and lots of winking along the way.

If you like Le Carre, this is an excellent way to say goodbye to the cold war, goodbye to Smiley and welcome in the next age of espionage.

Fun read. Bitter-sweet. And the wealth of characters is incredible.

Title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (Harry Potter, #4)
Author: J.K. Rowling

Title: Watching Baseball Smarter: A Professional Fan's Guide for Beginners, Semi-experts, and Deeply Serious Geeks
Author: Zack Hample

Title: Inconceivable
Author: Ben Elton
My Review:
This is a book to read not before you're 30, married (or near-as) and have seriously considered children. Even better if you have one.

It starts out like a hilarious classic british comedy. I found myself laughing out loud in bed, reciting passages to my wife who laughed as well. It looks very closely on the intimacy of a married bedroom, with Ben Elton's flair for funny banter.

I loved the charecters. I was really rooting for them and the suspense of whether they'll make it or not was almost unbearable!

There are twists, there are turns, there is romance and there is that special feeling of London in the 90s-00s.

So if you like British comedy - brew up some Earl Gray with milk, get in bed next to your loved one, and start.
You may stay up much later than expected :)
5 Stars

Title: The Hunt for Red October (Jack Ryan, #3)
Author: Tom Clancy
My Review:
Fun thriller, keeps you at the edge of your sit and reads like a Hollywood movie.
It definately reflects the time where it is set - America and the Soviets are a real hot-cold rivalry, with Americans having a clear advantage in the war.

Clacy drops you up-close into the inner working of the US and Soviet Navy (what's plural for Navy?), as well as into the innermost offices of the CIA, Pentagon and the Kremlin.
It FEELS real, it FEELS like this is truely how things were, and it is fascinating.

ALso, the technicalities of submarines, sailing and flight are given in great detail, which also contributes to that realistic feeling. It's like you're really a fly on the wall.

I really liked it. 4-Stars (5 is reserved for "life changers". This was just fun).

Title: Instant Replay: The Green Bay Diary of Jerry Kramer
Author: Jerry Kramer

Title: A Clockwork Orange
Author: Anthony Burgess
My Review:
Ok this book has a ton of reviews so I'll try to say something original - for me, the was Dr. Jackyl and Mr. Hyde of the 1960s

They both deal with the same question:
Can I medically seperate the evil from the good?

But I feel like Clockwork Orange did it much better!
A. Because the writing is so good you can't put it down

B. Because it examines what would happen if it actually succeeded. And it doesn't just end there (no spoilers)

This idea, when played through, is fascinating

I also really liked how Burgess made the effort to tie up all the hints left earlier on.

And lastly - the language is AMAZING.
Top class book.
I need to read it again, maybe a bit slower, but it's like a car crash you just can't look away

Title: The Fellowship of the Ring (The Lord of the Rings, #1)
Author: J.R.R. Tolkien

Title: Second Foundation (Foundation #3)
Author: Isaac Asimov
My Review:
Fun and clever book
At some points it really wrenches your mind as so many people are lying/being tricked that you don't know what to believe and try to outsmart the author. Often, you fail.

There are some gaps and holes but overall the book is well crafted. The writing is very fast-paced and action-packed.

Much like the first book, it is mostly a political thriller.
And the science bits are excellent.

Unlike the first 2 books, this one kinda ends up nicely, with all the loose end tied up. It's not the end of the story, but at least it finishes cleanly.

4 Stars

Title: Wilhelm Tell
Author: Friedrich Schiller
My Review:
I read the Hebrew translation by Bialik

This was, I realized midway, a 19th century action "movie".
It's pretty quick, suspensful and overly dramatic.
The story is one of heroes against vilians, and the hand of God (which guides Tell through it all) saves the day

Really nice story, which gives insights into both 19th century culture and much older folk tales (I read later Tell lived in the 14th century. Probably)

The third level of culture insight comes from the Bialik translation, which is early-20th-cent. Hebrew.
This is so different from the modern dialekt, and also from the ancient one it was a real joy to catch a glimpse of how the language looked midway through the transition - in Hebrew's revival.

Recommended!

Title: 2061: Odyssey Three (Space Odyssey, #3)
Author: Arthur C. Clarke
My Review:
Straight Sci-Fi.
Loved it.
If you liked the first and the second, this is really along the same lines.
Not a masterpiece, but a fun, fast, curious book to read over Christmas, a long holiday or in bed during sick leave.

Title: The Man in the High Castle
Author: Philip K. Dick
My Review:
It wasn't THAT bad
But it just disappointed me.

The good:
- The concept was cool: how would the world look like if the axis won WW2

- The writing was (most of the time) crisp and interesting. Picking up a lot of influence from Japanese and German - intentionally

- There are a few motives which apear again and again: books, jewels, clothes... it was interesting to follow them and hunt them out

The bad:
- It started off great but... after about 30% you realize that it has nothing more to say. The point has already come across.

- It gets better again, morpging into action with some very exciting bits and twists but loses touch near the end when you realize he couldn't possibly tie all the loose ends and he just leaves them.

It feels sloppy, like the author had some briliant ideas but not really a full book

Overall - that's how it fely. Briliant idea, sloppy excecution

Title: Discourse on Method and Meditations on First Philosophy
Author: René Descartes
My Review:
While I can see why it was briliant at the time, it has aged badly.

The style is terrible... Descartes writes with long complex sentences and big words for no good reason, his arguments are both simple and badly explained at the same time.

But really, his ideas feltobvious to me, or ridiculous. Maybe because I "did my homework" and read about the book before approaching the text.

Anyways - a good lecture is better than the book.
Not recommended

Title: A Perfect Spy
Author: John le Carré
My Review:
Good, long, Le Carre style

This book feels like John Le Carre, being a famous writer already, just allowed himself a free ride to write the book like he likes.

That means that the style is still his briliant style, the suspense is pretty good, and the social/political criticism is sharp BUT

It's a bit too long, a bit like a Jazz album where the music is very nice but you don't want to actually hear ALL of it.

I would recommend to the fans but not to the casual reader. If you're wondering where to start, go for the earlier books.

Title: The Knights
Author: Aristophanes
My Review:
Of the several plays I read from Aristophanes, this one was the crudest...
I don't know the history too well, but it feels like he was trying to make the point too much

Title: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (Harry Potter, #1)
Author: J.K. Rowling
My Review:
I have re-read it for (I think) the 4th time in my life.
This review is about the last re-read, at age 29, after college, married with a child.

It is an absolute show of Craft from Rowling. The style, while childish, still keeps you on the edge of your seat. It doesn't matter that I know the story by heart, read the book before and saw the movie, I have forgotten the nuances, the thrill of anticipation, the joy of the bizarre. Reading about the Harry Potter world enveloped me with nostalgia, curiosity and a warm feeling like good Earl Gray with milk.

I can't believe how well it is written from a stylistic point of view. I read all genres, times and authors and I can really appreciate good use of language - Rowling is VERY good. That is a point I missed as a child.

I will revisit the rest of the series again, and probably Sorcerer's Stone too, perhaps when my child reaches the proper age to join Hogwarts.

Title: מבחר סיפורים
Author: Sholom Aleichem
My Review:
I actually didn't read this version but the Librivox one. But still:
Really cool use of language, mixing old and new, biblical and common and amazing old words which today have lost their meaning. I really enjoyed the colorful language.

The stories really come alive and the people are very believable, you honestly doubt whether it's fiction or real stories (and the truth probably lies somewhere in between). For me, it's a glance at family history, at how my great-grandparents probably lived - how Jewish life looked like in 19th century Eastern Europe.

Really fun read!

Title: Flatland: A Romance of Many Dimensions
Author: Edwin A. Abbott
Additional Authors: Banesh Hoffmann, Masolino D'Amico, Giorgio Manganelli

Title: 2010: Odyssey Two (Space Odyssey, #2)
Author: Arthur C. Clarke
My Review:
I will try to explain my 4 stars.
It really deserves 5, it's well written, suspenseful, thought provoking... I really liked it BUT
It stands in the shadows of 2001, which was a full star better!
So. If 2001 could have gotten 6, it would. But since we are limited: 4/5 for this excellent thriller.

PS. You must read the first to get the second

Title: The Torah: The Five Books of Moses
Author: Anonymous
My Review:
Feels unfair to review it as a book.
But still.
I recommend anybody who lives in western culture, and especially anybody who is Jewish to read this once - from start to finish.

You will understand the culture better, you will get why is religion the way it is, why are Orthodox the way they are. You will understand our modern world better.

It's not an easy read, large parts are fairly boring - but it is a good book to know.
The first book, by the way, is the most enjoyable read. All the basic stories you know are from there and it's surprising how strange the world used to be.

Title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (Harry Potter, #3)
Author: J.K. Rowling

Title: Discourse on Method
Author: René Descartes
My Review:
Maybe because I am a scientist, but I found most of it to be obvious, and the writing style was EXHAUSTING.

He really was quitecan annoying guy, this Descartes... It is basically a long ramble on what is true and how do you know, but it goes on and on to extreme meaningless descriptions.

I recommend you read ABOUT this text rather than the actual, original version. It just did not stand the test of time (for me...)

Title: The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde
Author: Robert Louis Stevenson
My Review:
Surprisingly gripping!
Review for the Librivox Audio version

I was surprised at how gripping the story was! The sad part is that you knew the ending because it is so well known in pop-culture. But the suspenseful style was very good, the descriptions were deeply moving and overall, it was a very enjoyable read.

What puts this book very high on my list was the philosophy of it
I don't think these are spoilers, but... Dr. Jeckyl becomes Mr. Hyde when he drinks the drug. But what is the drug here?
You can think about it as alcohol or drugs or any substance abuse which brings out a decent man's "evil" side. That is one level.

On a different level, I liked to think: what an extraordinary concept, for a physician to look for a chemical solution to the problem of EVIL. That's an old old science which regards evil as a physical part of us. But it begs the question, assuming it is... what happens if we were to actually remove it.
And answers it, in detailed thought

Bottom line: A fun, chilling at times, stimulating read.

Title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (Harry Potter, #2)
Author: J.K. Rowling
My Review:
Much much better that I remembered!
It's amazing how different this book reads at age 13 and at age 30.
Only now could I appreciate what a clever little "murder-mystery" it is.
As a kid, I only enjoyed the magical world part of this book. I found the plot just distracting.

But today, re-reading so many years later, I suddenly realized that it really is a very good book.
Only shame is that I knew how it ends, so there was not a lot of suspense.

Title: The Man Who Would Be King
Author: Rudyard Kipling

Title: The Spy Who Came In from the Cold
Author: John le Carré

Title: The Russia House
Author: John le Carré
Additional Authors: Michael Jayston, René Basilico, Tom Baker

Title: A Murder of Quality (George Smiley #2)
Author: John le Carré
My Review:
Perfect for Christmas!
What a wonderful murder mystery
This book is super suspenseful, but also written in the special colorful style of John Le Carre: shady charachters, lies, cold weather and dark forests. I really got sucked in.
I honestly found myself changing my opinion on who the killer was several times and feel a bit 'played with' by Le Carre's crafty use of the characters involved.

Last note: this book is PERFECT for Christmas, it's not very long, it is well written and the atmosphere is very cold and snowy. Also, this book was written 50 years ago but the language is not dated, only the setting, which for me made it even more fun

Title: Foundation and Empire (Foundation #2)
Author: Isaac Asimov
My Review:
Not as good as the first but still well written.
You really should read Foundation before taking this one.

Title: The Fellowship of the Ring (The Lord of the Rings, #1)
Author: J.R.R. Tolkien
My Review:
There's not a lot to say to someone debating whether or not to read it, but here is my impression. The book is literally "Escapism". It takes you, with beautiful language and a special patience, to a fantasy land. To middle earth. It takes you to a world with no phones, no electricity and no artificial light. It manages to let you tour this world, in great detail and almost smell it. Everything is described fully and richly.

The story is quite compelling (and obviously, I watched the movie before).

The weak point is that this rich style can get tiring, and for me the use of songs or "Elven Language" was taking it too far. It made the book drag along. But, maybe, this patience is also part of the fantasy

Title: The Gods are Athirst
Author: Anatole France
My Review:
Well... It was interesting, the characters surprising, there was some drama and a lot of history, but... not sharp enough.

The bad:
- There wasn't much of a point, it was very "french" in that way where there are a lot of words with little substance.
- You probably need to know some history to enjoy, it's based on the assumption that you know who are the Jacobins, who is Marat and which are the key figures around the French revolution. I felt a little left out.

The good:
- It's a beautiful depiction of the time of Robspierre's terror regime, up close and personal.
- It is also a sharp criticism of politics (which remains fresh even today, 100+ years later).
- There's a lot of colour and some magnificent scenes, such as when a prostitute, an atheist and a monk share a bedroom as friends, under the reign of terror.
- I liked the charterers, I would tell my wife before I went to bed "well let's see what's going on with my French people"

Overall, it was just meh. 3-stars.

Title: A Selection of Oscar Wilde's Short Stories
Author: Oscar Wilde
My Review:
These are very dark and sharp versions of children's stories.
They really aren't for children but rather written as social comment on the relations between the rich and the poor.

The language is both incrediably elegant and childish at the same time - which is really impressive. Also, the writing is rich with descriptions and similies.

The weaker parts are that the morals are pretty obvious and all elements of suspense or "reason to turn the page" are sort of missing, but maybe that's why they're short...

P.S
Included here is the story 'The Selfish Giant', which has been a favorite of mine since early childhood. Until I came across this collection, however, I had absolutely no idea it was written by Wilde.

Title: Past Mortem
Author: Ben Elton
My Review:
Fast paced, murder case which gets crazier at every page.
Like in all Ben Elton, his book combines quick action and is his way to comment on society (lengthily...)

The characters are great, the details exquisite. I really found myself on the edge of my seat and gulped the whole book pretty fast

One thing to point out - it is VERY graphic. There is sex and violence all over.

Title: The Ode Less Travelled: Unlocking the Poet Within
Author: Stephen Fry
My Review:
Hard to review, since it took me a very long time, and was dropped and picked up again many times.

If you like Stephen Fry - you will like the style.
This book is basically your own private course on Poetry from Fry. You can really hear his special voice and style.

As for the topic: it's supposed to be a guide for someone who wants to pick up the hobby. I wasn't a fan of poetry but now I find it really interesting. It taught me a lot of how the whole thing is structured, what is meter, what is a sonnet and a ballad etc. Now I read other things (especially Shakespeare and Chaucer) and enjoy them more.
And as for picking up the hobby - I did, and I really like it.

One last point: I started this book specifically because it was Stephen Fry, and it was available to me. I did not care about poetry on any such thing.

Title: The Importance of Being Earnest
Author: Oscar Wilde
My Review:
Briliant and funny!
Written with flair and style that is the specialty of Wilde.
This short play pokes at the o
English Society (and I mean Society with a capital S).
Highly recomended short read

Title: All Quiet on the Western Front
Author: Erich Maria Remarque

Title: The Count of Monte Cristo
Author: Alexandre Dumas
My Review:
This was too big for me.
It's not just the sheer length (which everybody knows about), but what's inside.
The plot was amazing, full of twists and turns, philosophical thought, worthy heroes, smart tricks...
but it was all drowned in minute details, describing each room to the molecular level some times. It certainly gives color and life to the work, but for me it was too much.

The same goes for the complexity of the relations. Too many people, with too many names, titles, relations. And half the time they just call them sir or madame and it's hard to follow.

It is by all means, a masterpiece, but unlike a painting where you can enjoy the overall picture without noticing the minor brushstrokes which make it special, here, you feel like you have to read every word. And that was rather tiresome (even in the audio version).

Bottom line: it was too big for me. I will probably not attempt it again for a very long time.

Title: The Gun Seller
Author: Hugh Laurie
My Review:
I dropped this book into 3 stars after reading it the second time (5+ years later). So maybe I have changed.

I honestly can say I did not like the plot. It felt kind of silly and unplanned.

On the flipside, the main charachter, Lang, kept me coming back again and again. He's a bit like a combination of Wooster, House and James Bond all in one super clever, witty man.
But the way he got out of scrapes is well... like in James bond movies. I expected more sophistication.

Title: Foundation (Foundation, #1)
Author: Isaac Asimov
My Review:
Fun through and through.

This is a strange form of science fiction in that it is political. There are spaceships, technology and adventure, but above all it looks at political ideas in another world. Very well written and enjoyable (except the names...)

I had two problems with this book
1. There are no women in it. It is quite old fashioned in that all the charachters read like white American men, and they are all quite "Hollywoodish"

2. It doesnt end! Sorry if this is a spoiler but it ends completely open for a sequel! I was disappointed

Title: סוס אחד נכנס לבר
Author: David Grossman
My Review:
This was an interesting read, especially because the style was very fast, witty and sharp - almost entirely told by a stand-up comedian on the stage, jokes, jabs and quick wit included. The book plays along the lines of comfort, too close to comfort and detachment and rattles and dazzles you throughout the comedian's tale.

The book was deceptively engaging through the first half, but didn't live up to it's own hype in the end. I felt a little strung along the way forceforfully, especially near the end, but that might have been the writer's intention.

I have to say that even though I finished the book quickly, was touched by some parts, laughed aloud in others I think it's only worth the 3-stars. Mostly because I was disappointed with how the author wrote the last parts, which was both rushed and too long in my opinion. As if not well edited.
There is a lot that can probably be notched up to art, but I didn't like it.

Also, the jokes were great.

Title: Doomsday Book (Oxford Time Travel, #1)
Author: Connie Willis
Additional Authors: Rafael Marín Trechera, Daniel Dos Santos

Title: A Brief History of Time
Author: Stephen Hawking
My Review:
It has a few gems, and quite a lot of physics which the writer tried to put in simple terms.
However, it is both too simplified to give you a proper understanding or too complex to be a fun read.

I learned a little, thought about physics a lot. But overall, I can't really recommend

Title: Dreaming the Dark
Author: Elana Gomel
Publisher: The Reckless imprint of Candlemark & Gleam

Title: The Book of Chuang Tzu
Author: Zhuangzi
Additional Authors: Burton Watson, Martin Palmer, Elizabeth Breuilly

Title: Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?
Author: Philip K. Dick
My Review:
Exceptional.
One of the few books I read that have all 3:
Thrilling
Touching
Thought provoking
(I should call it the 3 Ts...)

It is a fast paced book, written in a Hollywood movie style of action, in a sci-fi apocalyptic universe. Ye at the same time you find a LOT of social / cultural criticism. I felt the writer had a lot to say about religion, and life fulfilment and their relation to each other. It is not a lecture on ethics! It is a nice story which makes you think but gives no clear answers.

Highly recommended!

Title: Mostly Harmless (Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy, #5)
Author: Douglas Adams
My Review:
It really felt like Adams was ready to finish the whole thing up.
His pool of ideas wasn't as full, except for one large concept of multi-dimensionality which he really tried to get across and a few jokes it feels like he's been saving for years.
This is not to say this is a bad book. It is still funny, clever, and a fun read. It is however not as smooth, not as polished, not as good as the rest.

I remember after I read it the first time around I really didn't like it, but now in the second read I enjoyed the sophistication and depth of the jokes that I did not notice when the plot was too fresh.

If you enjoyed more than one book in the series, you should read it through. And multiple times.

Title: The Jungle Book
Author: Rudyard Kipling
My Review: This collection of short stories may have been intended for children but I thoroughly enjoyed it as an adult. Kipling's way of storytelling is compelling in it's use of simple language, laced with indian terms and exciting pace. It is probably not good for modern children as there's quite a lot of violence, hunting and killing in there, but for me it was another way to look at history and biology, through magical short stories on animal life

Title: Guide to Stoicism
Author: St. George Stock
My Review:
This review is for the Librivox audio version

It was a difficult one, it's surprisng how such a short book demands so much attention for you to enjoy.
The style was very academic so every word seems to have been carefully picked and the amount of repetition is tiny - you really have to stay focused to follow along. The problem is that it is both taxing on your ming and quite a boring style at the same time!

On the good side, I did learn a lot about the stoics quite quickly, and I feel I have a better understanding of their philosophy today than I did before.

Not recommended to anyone as a guide to how to be a stoic, or as an introduction to the subject but rather as an comprehensive (albeit short) guide to the stoic's way of thinking

Title: So Long, and Thanks for All the Fish (The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy, #4)
Author: Douglas Adams
My Review:
Not as good as the first ones,
but still it has a warm place in my heart.
I know all the jokes and all the stories by heart, but still find myself laughing.
Douglas Adams is (or rather was) the best

Title: The Age of Fable
Author: Thomas Bulfinch
My Review:
Very hard to rate this book.
It was interesting, I learned a ton, but it was like reading a textbook.
While the author really made an effort to write fluently and in prose he was also meticulous not to miss details or overlook facts.

This book is essentially a collection of Greek, Roman,Egyptian, Norse and German mythology (Mostly Greek) accompanied by poetry that relates to the subject. The premise of the book is that "Today" (written in the 19th cent.) people who read poetry don't get all the allusions to the myths so - a collection of the stories with poetry samples is needed.

Overall it really is an immense piece of work (though not very long), full of great tales and very "horizon-widening" BUT it's also a long list of characters with no plot or suspense...
Hard read, but worth it.

Title: The Constant Gardener
Author: John le Carré
My Review:
Very difficult to rate this book.
On the one hand, the first 70% of it was quite boring, I had to work through it, almost gave up on the book. I felt it was going too slow and nothing wasn't happening.
The second 30% was not amazing, but decent. You would expect this book to be a 2-3 star affair.
BUT
Beyond the not-se-interesting plot and not-so-interestong charachters I found myself thinking about this book all day. About the dillemas it poses, about the third world, about the connection between pharmaceuticals and governments, the effect big companies from all over the world have in weaker places. All the moral dillemas were in my mind all day long, especially near the end.
That is why this book is good. It's not an excellent thriller or drama, but rather a pointy philosophical work on inequality and the place money has in our modern societies.

And this is not a spoiler, but I have to say that while Le Carre presents it as pretty evil, I found a lot of good behind it.

Recommended, but know that it takes some patience

Title: A Moveable Feast
Author: Ernest Hemingway
My Review:
I find this book very hard to describe.
There is no linear storyline, no suspense. There however a great atmosphere of the dashing life in the literary circles of 20s Paris. With details as to the cafes, streets, cheap living, wine and friends.
It's an inoccent story, about an inoccent time and an inoccent couple, who are poor but happy.
The writing is pretty, in a rough kind of way. It's not a gem but it flows well.
Makes you want to write.
Sorry if thiswas unhelpful, but I would recommend this to anyone who wants/needs to write something (be it his novel, university thesis, scientific paper or anything) or any young poor couple. It will make you happy and excited about both.

Title: How to Visit an Art Museum ：Tips for a truly rewarding visit
Author: Johan Idema

Title: גירושים מאוחרים
Author: A.B. Yehoshua
My Review:
Excellent writing! The style and technique were very unique, with each chapter being written from the point of view of another character, and in fluent stream of consciousness. It made you see the same issues from different points of view and appreciate the characters connotations and opinions.

This style along with the very touching, mysterious and ever entangling storyline makes this one a home run. In a nutshell, an old Israeli is coming back from America to get a divorce from his wife, after many years. His children, who live in Israel, help the couple with the process even though the reason for the sudden divorce, and the circumstances for the original estrangement are not clear to the reader. page by page, family secrets and motives are peeled away, and the complicated relationships between them all unveil.

It is amazing how much the writer had to SAY. About God, Love, Family, ambition and disappointment from all of the above. It is both obvious and hidden. I personally found myself thinking about the book a lot between reads. Enjoying the underlying messages and truths about life.

Highly recommended!

Title: Chart Throb
Author: Ben Elton
My Review:
Another hit by Ben Elton
Elton shines a very unattractive light on the music-talent reality TV shows and on society in general. With a flair for common language, Elton makes a story where honestly - everyone is a villian. He shows how society can act idiotically, how manipulation and deceit are part of our everyday lives and how, most disturbing of all, we can all see it but choose not to.

I don't want to make it sound like some tearful drama, it's a black comedy if ever there was one. It's funny (sometime in a laugh out loud way and some in a "well that was very clever" smirking way) and the story line is gripping.

Highly recommended fun read!

Title: Life, the Universe and Everything (Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy, #3)
Author: Douglas Adams
My Review:
Douglas Adams not at his best.
Still funny, clever, sometimes thought provoking, but not as sharp as you've come to expect.

Probably would have gotten 4 stars if it was not by this author...

Title: The Guide for Graduate Science Research: Over 200 Sanity-Saving Tips for Graduate Student Scientists
Author: Maya Benami
Additional Authors: Sarah Lizer Solomon, Mary Benami, Dominic Standing, Carolyn Jourdan
My Review:
These are very good tips. I am between finishing my MSc and starting my PhD and these tips are really exactly what you need for doing research for the first time.

The problems with the book are that it's a bit repetitive, it collects tips from a few scientists and, honestly, they are mostly the same. Also, a lot of times the language is overtring to make the tip global.

I would really recommend it to anyone who's going to do his research for the first time, even if they already started. It's probably a bit much for someone just starting but once you get a bit of a roll going - perfect.

Title: פרס גפן 2015
Author: רותם ברוכין
Additional Authors: הילה בניוביץ'-הופמן, Keren Landsman, Roni Gelbfish
My Review:
I took this short story collection simply because it was free, in Hebrew and sounded like it may be interesting... I really got a lot out of it.

Each one of the stories (excluding the first which I really didn't like) was just the right length, and just the right dose of "crazy". These short stories were surprisingly ingenious and complicated and yet, in about a 1-hour read you got the message and the alternative universe they offered clarified into something very original.

Highly recommended for any sci-fi fan (that can read Hebrew...).
the book is (or at least was) available for free from Mendele.co.il
Recommended For: Sci fi fans that can read Hebrew

Title: 2001: A Space Odyssey (Space Odyssey, #1)
Author: Arthur C. Clarke
My Review:
Gripping.
I'd highly recommend watching the movie BEFORE reading the book, this is strange advice but then again the movie is a strange movie and the book a strange book.

I will not reiterate the story, but I will say that it works on several levels:
1) It's a fun action-suspense novel. It twists, it turns, the characters are realistic and the story is a gripping one.
2) It stretches your imagination - the story takes place in the future, in space, and makes you wonder and marvel at the possibilities, challenges and beauty that these space explorations entail. It is written beautifully and cleverly so as to stretch your imagination, with a strong base of science, physics, astronomy and biology.
3) It is a philosophical work - it poses famous philosophical questions and puts them in realistic scenarios and asks the reader WHAT WOULD YOU DO? or WHAT DO YOU THINK? This thought provoking style is sometime subtle, and sometimes kicks you in the head.

All could equally be said about the movie, the reason I recommend watching the movie first is because the book is a version of the film where you can slow things down, take it in your own time, notice the details and so forth. The movie is like a quick read of the book, a scanning glance. You get the main points but miss some of the subtlety. And this book deserves attention to all the detail.

Title: The Invention of Nature: Alexander von Humboldt's New World
Author: Andrea Wulf

Title: Old New Land
Author: Theodor Herzl
My Review:
Every Israeli citizen (and probably jew) should read this.
This is the "dream/Prophecy" of Theodor (Binyamin Ze'ev) Herzl. It tells the story of a sad Austria-Jewish lawyer who decided t quit the world and goes off to a desolate island. On his way there he stops to see Israel (Palestine) as the land of his fathers. He finds it dirty, poor and full of bandits.

20 years later he returns to see how the world changes, stopping again in Israel. He finds a 1900s Utopia. Cities, railways, electricity and phones. Equality, cooporation, cultural diversity. He finds and describes this land as he wishes it to be - 100 years ago.

Today, as a citizen of modern-day Israel, it is amazing to read this book, written almost as a science fiction novel, completely realized. It is jaw-dropping to read Hertzl's dream of Jerusalem, with it's modern rails and cooperation between Jews and Arabs - IN the modern Jerusalem, with it's rail, wifi, top university and (you may not believe this if you're abroad) cooperation between Jews and Arabs.

I was highly influenced by this book. It is incredible to seehow accurate the prophecy was, and see us as a society not even notice.

Also, the language is a strange old dialect of hebrew, which is very clear to read but also very strange. It "smells" of Yiddish and trying very hard to write in a new language. Areal pleasure for language lovers.

Title: A Planet of Viruses
Author: Carl Zimmer
My Review:
Nice, short and to the point. As a microbiologist, I have a strange relationship with viruses. Since they are officially in our field I am expected to understand what's going on there, but they are so strange most microbiologist (myself included) shrink away from them. So this book was a great bridge to help me connect with my inner virologist.

It mentions a few prime examples of interesting viruses, goes through the history of how they were discovered and what is their importance and all in a clear and concise matter. The best part is how the writer describes early experiments and the thought process leading up to them. It's not a life changer, but a nudge and a fun read nonetheless.

Title: Othello
Author: William Shakespeare
My Review:
WOW

This is one of those works where you can really tell what made it into such a classic. Everything about it was above and beyond - the language, structure, plotline, twists and scenery.
I can honestly say I almost cried near the end, and my gut wrenched with anger, suspense and deep sympathy for the heroes.

Like very old whiskey, it's both subtle and a kick in the face, and definitely not easy to swallow. But once you are mature enough, have good control of language and want something a little special - this is the read for you.

PS - I read most of it aloud to myself, it significantly improved it.

Title: Breakfast of Champions
Author: Kurt Vonnegut Jr.
My Review:
** update after second read **
A person should read this book twice or more, the messages are deep and painful, and need to seep in slowly. Vonnegut had a lot to say about the world, he had sharp criticism, he had insights into human nature, and he had a load to get off his chest. I was very moved. It is amazing how well this man can write, where the language is simple to the point of childish, but the ideas are sharp, piercing insights. The characters all had incredible depth and there was a lot not obvious to the eye. I really enjoyed it the second time around, and will probably read it again later

** Original review **
I have consumed this book in one great gulp.
Reading it on breaks while in full-active-operational-duty or whatever, fighting for home in Israel.
It has left me in awe as to how much a book can affect your mood and point of view. I can't remember ever waiting to have free time so I can actually "hear" more of this strange tale.
I think Ill re-read it soon, because it just evaporated from my grip too fast...
Great thought provoking book

Title: The Little Book of Hygge: The Danish Way to Live Well
Author: Meik Wiking
My Review:
Exactly what it says on the cover - it's about Hygge, the Danish way to live well.
This generally includess cake, warm fires, candles, blankets, wine and friends. The problem is that this is about it, the writer backs it up with data and rich description but generally this idea is not worth a whole book.
Throught it I kept thinking that this would make a great magazine article, but a book? You really don't have that much to say...

On the up side, the messege is clear and interesting, the examples make you want to go ahead and implement (like, watching the stars on a dark hill with friends, a fire and a bottle of whiskey or reading a book with a cup of coffee and snow in the window...)
Cute book to have around, but not a home-run.

Title: Revolt in 2100
Author: Robert A. Heinlein
My Review:
Cool ideas, not well done.
The book is a futuristic sci-fi book that is split into 3 stories (which sort of follow each other in chronology but the connections are vague to non-existent)

The first which is the longest and weakest is about a dystopian religious America, where a prophet rules the country in a very Orwellian way (1984-ish), and a revolt against said prophet. I don't want to spoil it but my biggest problem was the inconsistency: the hero ditches his whole life philosophy several times and not for good reasons and characters make huge impact and are then forgotten about, only to be used again to badly tie their own loose ends. This inconsistency and loose-ends make this story seem thoughtless and carelessly written.

The other 2 stories are about the future after the revolt. they are much shorter and are thus less damaged by inconsistencies (though still not very well done). The best part about these is the insight into the world of technology and engineering, seen through the eyes of a former military engineer.

Generally this is the brightest spot in this book - Heinlein, a former army engineer, writes compellingly about rocketry, space, flight and underground excavations. He appears to both understand the issues of trying to live on an airless, gravity-free asteroid and offer futuristic plausible solutions for them. Which makes the writing special and unique, at least in my opinion.

FYI - if you're looking for realistic characters, especially female ones, look elsewhere.

Title: Mythos: The Greek Myths Retold (Stephen Fry's Great Mythology, #1)
Author: Stephen Fry

Title: Smiley's People (George Smiley #7; Karla Trilogy #3)
Author: John le Carré
My Review:
Most of Le Carre's books have left me with a taste for more... but in this one the writer (perhaps intentionally?) felt old. The pace was very slow, the attention to detail which I usually like about him was lulling me to sleep. It was just a weak book for a good writer.

It does finish the series up pretty well. A lot of old-school spies trying to land the "big fish" for the last time. And there's a lot of interesting "tradecraft" and so forth.

So, I wouldn't recommend it as a spy book, just as a good finish to a great series of books about the excellent character - George Smiley.

Title: שרלוק הולמס כל הסיפורים - כרך א
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
Additional Authors: רות שמעוני, חנה לבנת, מיכאל הנדלזלץ
My Review:
I was really pleasantly surprised by this book.
Its a collection of lots of short stories of Sherlock Holmes' adventures with his biographer Watson.

I was surprised because you start this read thinking that you know the characters and that its going to be (like most classics) too slow and blunted by time.
But no. this book's greatness is in its simplicity within complexity. it has complex (beautiful) language, complex characters and very complex plots. On the other hand, the stories are told by a "simple" narrator in Watson, its short-story format makes the problems be solved simply and succinctly and finally, its told in a "simpler" time and setting. They go around in horse-drawn chalices, EVERYBODY smokes and there are no cellphones. this makes things very simple and approachable, but very complex - and that duality is what makes it great.

Cheers to sir Arthur Conan Doyle.
He had me gripped for a story each time and made me think harder than I expected to try and solve his unsolvable puzzles

Title: Brave New World
Author: Aldous Huxley
My Review:
This book tells an interesting tale.
It's basically the future Aldous Huxley thought is "coming" in about 600 years. In this future everything is very nicely set up, monitored and simple, and everybody (well, almost...) is happy.
The whole story is told from the eyes of an unhappy person in this "Perfect" future society.

The book is very fun, interesting and even thought provoking up till about halfway through.
It seams the author poses the question of "would you like to live in this world?" up to about that point. After this part, in my opinion, the book takes a bit of a down-turn.
It's still a good book, but much differentrly.
While the first half mostly deals with the little guy inside the big 'Society' machine, the second deals mostly with the drama of the clash betweet the un-"civilized" and the "civilized".
Interesting, but I really felt the first half didn't quite finish right before jumping to the second.

Fair Warning - The book is very psychological and sociological and tends to go on a bit on theories regarding those subjects, so if you get bores with that sort of stuff, you might want to skip it.

Sorry for all the quote marks in this review, but I think they fit.

Author: George Orwell
Additional Authors: Erich Fromm, Regina Silveira, Amazing Améziane, Marcelo Pen, Golo Mann, Harald Sachse, Irving Howe, Raymond Williams, Thomas Pynchon, Homi K. Bhabha, Martha C. Nussbaum, Bernard Crick, George Packer
My Review:
What makes this book great (in my opinion) is NOT it's social comment, but the way in which the author manages to stir you through his words.
You actually feel angry, frustrated, relieved, stressed, afraid (not exactly...) and all this range of strong emotions come to you through words on a page. I had been moved almost to tears, I had to put down the book when I got too stressed and take a few deep breaths or even put it away until tomorrow. It got me worked up.
It is tremendously moving.

Further, it manages to touch upon the subject of freedom and show you how important it is, and how in some way your biggest fear is losing it. There is some rambling parts of ideology which, to my taste, are a bit superfluous but generally the book is fast paced and yet has a lot to say.

One of the few classics I have read that are worthy of its respect.

PS - interestingly, I didn't think it was 5-star-worth my first time round... only in my 2nd read.

Title: Fahrenheit 451
Author: Ray Bradbury
My Review:
This book was excellent. I ate it right up, it was thought provoking and the characters were very touching.
The premise is interesting - in a future world, people attention spans are practically non-exsistant and firemen's jobs are no longer putting out fires (technology took care of that) but rather burning books.
It was interesting to see that the same fears and worries we have today were very much existing in the 50s; the youth no longer read, people are becoming more and more shallow, TVs (or screens) are making everyone into couch potatoes and big corporations are controlling our thoughts under the radar. It could have just as well been written today.

The most touching part is the relationships between the hero and his wife. In a world of TVs and nothing else, how can you reach intimacy, human interaction and understanding? The most piercing were the thoughts of the hero thinking what if I could build my own radio station, could I whisper in my wife's ear?

The ending kinda ruined it, it felt like the ideas were there but how to wrap it all up was done quickly and not with good flow... that's at least my opinion.
Probably need to read it again.

Title: As You Like It
Author: William Shakespeare
My Review:
The happy "everything-fits-into-place" ending pulled an extra star for it.
The fact that it's all written in pretty good meter pulled one also.
But the story isn't very good, the language is both difficult and sometimes too circumventive and the characters are not silly enough for funny and not smart enough for depth...

But it's a short, and teaches you about the history of language, culture and love.
Probably better on stage...

DO NOT expect to laugh out loud, there are few jokes (at least to my notice).

Title: Penguin Island
Author: Anatole France
My Review:
One of the best books I've ever read. Sharp satire going through history from the early 4-5th century all the way to modern and future times.

France tells the story as if told by an uninterested historian, making reality itself the comedian. While all the names and places are fictional they are a very clear allusion to French history. He mocks religion by making a prostitute a saint by trickery, talking about the pious and poor monks who run a distillery and think about money. And the prime minister who, trying to avoid scandal, arrests more socialists and promises reforms he never accomplishes.

While the book is definately funny and absurd, it is also very realistic and relevant. It is over 100 years old but you can absolutely relate the events in the book to te events in your newspaper.

Lastly, I applaud the amount of philosophy and thought put into this book. Mixed in with all the joking and finger pointing, there is a lot of thought provoking truths screaming from this book.

I would recommend it to anyone who appreciates a sharp, smart comedy or satire. Be it from TV shows, comedians or books. You will find this just as accurate and more intelligent than what you've met so far.

Title: The Path of the Just - מסילת ישרים
Author: Moshe Chayim Luzzatto

Title: Diamonds Are Forever
Author: Ian Fleming
My Review:
Just like the movies: fast, witty, lots of action, pretty girl and (let's face it) quite cheap and sleezy.
Buy I had a great deal of fun reading this book. And there's the added value of the eye into very "old-school" luxuries of the 50s and 60s like riding a plane that has a dinner room, or bunk beds...
parts about the history of American gangsters and Las Vegas and more.
Also I learned a bit about drinks which is always fun ("whiskey and branch water" google it)

Generally recommended as a good entertaining read. Not much more. Probably perfect for a plane ride.

PS - It's very chauvinistic and racist... if you mind that sort of thing you may wish to avoid. very "50s" in that sense.

Title: The Woman Who Died a Lot (Thursday Next, #7)
Author: Jasper Fforde
My Review:
The best in the series.
This book is written in the same quick and witty style of Jasper Fforde, but somehow in this one he managed to cram incredibly clever ideas about time-travel and basic philosophy.
Highly recommended to all TN lovers and to anyone who likes a funny sci-fi book.

Title: The Pig That Wants To Be Eaten: And Ninety Nine Other Thought Experiments
Author: Julian Baggini
My Review:
The Good:
- The ideas given are put in clear language, and the arguments are concise. So you can get big ideas in short paragraphs and each thought experiment is about 2 pages long (with the analysis).
- The writer makes sure to give you both the source of the original philosophies AND modern examples that are relevant.
- The ideas are the big ideas of philosophy (I think...). So there really is a lot to think about.
- The sides of each arguments are given pretty much evenly and don't leave you with a simple answer but rather an understanding that most issues are gray and more complex than you thought.

Important note (I was going to write "the bad" but there's nothing wrong with this):
This is not a novel. There is no clear line of thought. each chapter is a short thought experiment.
This was sometimes good, but mostly annoying because you can't read more than a few pages at a time and it will not put you to sleep like most books...

So why 3-stars? Because it's a referance book. It did not move me, I did not relate to any characters, I did not get the nice warm feeling you get reading books. I only got introduced to some good philosophy

Title: The Extended Phenotype: The Long Reach of the Gene
Author: Richard Dawkins

Title: The Chicago Cubs: Story of a Curse
Author: Rich Cohen

Title: Slaughterhouse-Five
Author: Kurt Vonnegut Jr.
My Review:
I have changed it to 5-stars after reading for a second time.
Why?
Because beyond the fact that is is very well written, snappy, funny, relateable and touching, it also touches on some very deep points in life AND uses some amazingly clever writing tricks that you can only really appreciate when you start all over again.

It speaks about war, death and sorrow from a child's point of view, and from a calm and serene point of view - somehow doing both at the same time. These are not simple topics and to discuss them in such ways is impressive. Also the book manages to make you question time, cause and event sequences, the "pointlessness" of life and such and yet remain a funny and light read.
I reccommend this to all who have already read it and thought it to be OK . Read it again and it will really turn your mind inside-out.

Title: This Other Eden
Author: Ben Elton
My Review:
Great combination of a good twisty plot and interesting thought-provoking writing.
A lot of political comment (as fitting for a Ben Elton book) and very winding plot of world-wide intrigue, eco-terrorism, huge egos and Hollywood. The whole thing takes place in the nearer-than-you-think future where the environment essentially collapses. There is an enourmouse power struggle between the "greenies" who try to save what's left and the salesmen who try to sell as many post-armageddon kits.

Had it been a bit sharper in writing, a bit better-paced and with slightly deeper characters - it would've been a 5-star. This really is a slightly unpolished diamond.

Title: Mort (Discworld, #4; Death, #1)
Author: Terry Pratchett
My Review:
Not his best... but Pratchett not at his best is still funny, whacky, with great side stories and crazy logic. The plot itself is rather feeble (telling the tale of DEATH's apprentice, who falls in love with a princess he has to "kill").

The characters are eekily romantic and naive or just plain and bland, and the ideas behind the whole thing are not thoroughly thought out (so is the ending...).

So, to conclude, its a 3-star. funny, enjoyable, quick but not something that will stay with you for a long time afterwards.

Title: רוח פנימית
Author: איל פוליטי
My Review:
Sloppy work, trying to explain the conceptual idea of Chinese medicine through the 5-element methods, by transcribing the lectures of the writer.

This book has an interesting premise, but the writing is jittery, the ideas are not thouroughly explained and, honestly, its not well made (plenty of typos and grammer mistakes...)

However I have learned a lot and it has certainly opened a door for me to this field.

Title: The Histories
Author: Herodotus
Additional Authors: Aubrey de Sélincourt, John M. Marincola

Title: The Big Over Easy (Nursery Crime, #1)
Author: Jasper Fforde
My Review:
Wacky! Great murder-mystery, set up in a crazy alternative Reading, UK. Basically and without ruining anything - this is the story of a small-time detective trying to solve a super-complicated murder, in a world where Police-work is very tight to the entertainment world (so you want your investigations to have some penache).
The writing is crisp and very "Douglas-Adams" and the plot twists and turns at break-neck speed.

It was a bit like having peanut butter and jelly with a crazy-straw.

Highly recommended!

Title: The Button Guy
Author: Jasper Fforde
My Review:
Short story on an invented role called "The Button Guy", who is a sort of watchdog of democracy.
This story is quite thought provoking, especially near the end. It makes you think about the roles of government safety mechanism, what happens if they are outdated? If a democracy chooses to become dictatorial? Who decided to "loosen" safety procedures?

This is super relevant to any age, and Fforde makes this monologous story a sort of meditation on the subject.
Highly recommended

Title: Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy
Author: John le Carré
My Review:
Very well written, as befitting Le Carre's finest.
I think someone on the back-cover got it really right:
"There is a depth of characterization in... that you will find in no other espionage novel". Everybody there is not "good" or "bad", not "greedy" or "chivalrous". Every character is both at the same time, like in real life. And this, with the amazing ability of the writer to make you feel the situation with descriptive writing make this a home-run.

The only reason it didn't get the full 5 star is that I knew the story already from a BBC radio dramatization, so the twists didn't really have me on the edge of my seat.
Otherwise, this is really a great book.

Title: Equal Rites (Discworld, #3; Witches, #1)
Author: Terry Pratchett
My Review:
Good Pratchett.
Quick, witty and crazy.
Not really very "sound" plot. some holes were plugged a bit too ruggedly but generally its a whacky adventure of a girl who wants to become a wizard under the guidance of an old witch. The very premises is kinda amusing so in the hands of Pratchett it gets really funny, with a lot of side stories and anecdotes (like Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy)

With that, there is a great moral to the story, and it is a bit childish (especially with the main character being 8 years old)

Title: Heidegger and a Hippo Walk Through Those Pearly Gates: Using Philosophy (and Jokes!) to Explore Life, Death, the Afterlife, and Everything in Between
Author: Thomas Cathcart
My Review:
Read this a second time and all I have to say is... well, Ok.
the book gives a very quick (almost spastic) review of different aspects of death from the point of view of philoophers and social research. all wrapped in a "stand-up" comedy environment laced with jokes and slang.

While some of the ideas were quite thoughtprovoking, none are really thought-through. They could put up a question like "what would you die for?" add a a joke and a paragraph or so and jump to the next big idea... you can't really think it through or you'de have to stop and look up either other writers or really think about every other paragraph. Just not deep-enough to be "thought provoking" nor funny enough to be "comedy".

Title: Three Plays: The Wasps / The Poet and the Women / The Frogs
Author: Aristophanes
My Review:
Incredible.
2000 years later and these comedies are still sharp, relevant and funny!
Thanks to a great job by translater David Barret you really get the feel of the great theater in Athens.
The short introduction and introductions to each play get you up-to-speed without being wearisome and get you straight into the action.
One of the strangest things is how GRAPHIC (kind of like slapstick) this style of comedy is and you're enjoying it when reading.

I'm adding my specific reviews for the first 2 plays which I wrote as I read them.
The third review would be a waste so I'll just say that its a bit less funny and a bit more clever.
So you get 3 kinds of comedies here: Political, Graphic and Sophisticated (lyrical?)
Highly recomended to all who like history.

The Poet and the Women 5*
This was tremendously graphic, with actors flying from the walls, Bacchic dancing and a very intrusive interrogation to find out a man masquerading as a woman ("he put it between his legs!")
And yet - all comes vividly alive, the whole singing-dancing-zingy show thanks to great translation and the brilliance of the author.
Its like going through a time-machine and really taking part!

5* - its amazing how RELEVANT and funny this is, and only ink on paper - you can't actually see the action on the stage and yet it comes alive in your head.
The translator and the author's combining rhymes, meaning and funny zingers is incredible - especially when you realize that its all in perfect meter and rhythm (you can actually "sing along")

Title: In the Company of Microbes: Ten Years of Small Things Considered
Author: Moselio Schaechter

Title: A Little History of the World: Illustrated Edition
Author: E.H. Gombrich
My Review:
Its a brief review of the worlds history - as told to a kid (I'd say 10-14 years old).
I loved it. it siplifies and answers the questions I want answered.
The writer makes sure to always emphasize that if you want to know more you can read up on it (which I do often).

The best part about this book is that it explains what caused the transitions between the periods, and structures the timeline of a huge part of history.
Like the order of Greece --> Rome --> Middle ages is fairly well known, but where is confusius in this? and Muhammed?
things are very well framed and organized.

The reason this book only gets a 4 is 2-fold.
A. it really looses its patience and charm around modern times
B. it isn't THAT good. history is not a simple subject.

Very recommended to he young of heart and naturally interested in history
I didn't feel like this book is necessarily for children much the same way the King Solomon's Mines and other old-time adventures aren't.

Title: Time and Time Again
Author: Ben Elton
My Review:
In short: You get exactly what you think

- Ben Elton wrtiting, which I really like -
Crisp, personal, provocative both in imagery (he describes terrible wounds and nudity very lively) and in content (he goes on a bit of a "soapbox" about women rights and other moral issues) but with rather bland charecters. And still funny at times (though NOT A COMEDY)

- Time travel -
for those who like this sort of thing. its nice. not too many twists but a very exciting ending

- Historical setting -
most of the story occurs during WWI, around 1914 and is told from a modern man's perspective. which can be lots of fun (riding in a car without power-stirring, colonial views, no antibiotics...)


The problems are - the hero always gets out of the jam in a very "James Bond" way. Beating 4 attacker in hand-to-hand combat... Luckily avoiding being shot... Its a bit too easy at times.
Also in my opinion not enough twists and turns for a time-travel adventure book. Good suspense but not a lot of surprises.

Hope this helps
Cheers

Title: אלוהים יודע
Author: Joseph Heller
My Review:
Had it been shorter it would've got a 5
Any longer though it would've been a 3.

In short - this is the biblical story of King David, as told by Heller's version of David on his deathbed.
And its wild. He hates, he lies, he adultrates, he thinks he knows best...
all told with fascinating details and very clever anachronistic gems ("I wanted to send him a telegram, but we didn't have those...", talking about his statue by Michaelangelo...)

The good: It's very clever and jumpy, filled with intricacies and monarchy plots. God plays a key and very well written role. The prophets too.
Nothing is sacred - which is refreshing. Its both mocking religion and mocking the mockers.
and its very, very personal. As a man - I find this very interesting.

The bad: its not C-22. if you were expecting that. There is probably only one book like Catch 22 and thats Catch 22. Its also a bit long and it takes a while to remember and understand all the character's names and relations.
This doesn't apply to me... but you need some working knowledge of the biblical story (David-Saul, David-Bat Sheva, David-Goliath stories) otherwise you won't get the full impact.

Last minor note - I read this in hebrew, and though I didn't compare I think its best read in this language because all the charechters and places have their REAL names.

Title: Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea
Author: Jules Verne
My Review:
What a dull book...
its ending is pretty good but there are wayyy too many unanswered questions which are just left hanging...
its almost as if Verne was preparing the ground for a sequel. Another major problem is that ENTIRE CHAPTERS are filled with long lists of all the organisms in all the seas, its just plain dull!
The idea in general is cool but the characters are flat and unreal (Verne with his over-servantly servant and dumb Americans).
The biggest problem for me is that there is no clear line of plot, because the hero doesn't know where is he going or what is the point of the journey - neither does the reader and the entire plot just drifts around from piece to piece never making a coherent line.

Good points -
some chapters are highly suspenseful and really make you want to turn the page
The science is very very interesting, even though (maybe because its) highly old-fashioned
There are snippets of history or culture which are very nicely written.


Honestly - just don't.

Title: מגרש השדים
Author: נמרוד עופרן
My Review:
A collection of short articles on sports tragedies, very well written and very human.
Some shocking, other touching and a few maddening or just interesting - this book was written in plain language and straight for the heart.

I've learned the terrible phrase "corrective rape", and I've learned a bit about addiction and its consuming power over people. Mostly I've learned the importance of "The Sport" to athletes.

Great book, highly recommended.

Title: One of Our Thursdays Is Missing (Thursday Next, #6)
Author: Jasper Fforde
My Review:
Not Fforde at his finest, but fun. The BookWorld takes on new dimensions but it isn't very consistent and believeable (as much as a "BookWorld" could be believeable).
There's still suspence, wicked ideas and a few funny one-liners that are very clever, but the world around it isn't as compelling as it used to feel, and the characters are a bit repetetive.

I'll give Fforde a lot of credit for the last minute twist, and the build up to it - but throughout the book there were a lot of times when you think "did he forget about this?" or "did he just put that bit in for no reason?". It just isn't a very sharp mystery.

Still good fun though. I enjoyed it.

Title: Around the World in Eighty Days
Author: Jules Verne
My Review:
Very old and outdated - it gives a glimpse into the writer's thoughts about the world.
It kinda feels like Verne was trying to write a "taste the cultures of the globe" book for european children, explaining what are mangoes, who rules Hong-Kong, how Americans are so different than the Europeans etc... Reading it today though, in the age of the internet and global village - I know what are mangoes and how Americans are different, what I'm getting from this book is a look into the past of European culture abroad. With the Indians looked upon as slaves, islanders looked upon as barbarian cannibals and the American looked upon as a mob. It is beautiful.

As for criticism, the characters are very flat - Fogg is always impassive and cool, Passpartout is always childish and "servantly" and so on. Nobody ever thinks or acts outside their very limited frames. This might be a shame for some, but it makes the book very light and simple. Also while most difficulties are removed with clever tricks or "Eureka!" moments - they are almost always resolved in pretty much the same way.

One last note - even though deep down you know the ending, you really are at the edge of your sit as to "will they get out of this jam???".

Title: Three Days to Never
Author: Tim Powers
My Review:
The first half of this book is full of mystery and suspense.
The problem is that the second half doesn't really tie up all the knots or answer the questions...
It builds up and up and up and about 80 pages from the end you suddenly understand that nothing won't really resolve itself, and the last 50 pages are basically a mess (Don't really want to ruin it for you). Very disappointing finish to what felt like it would be a 4-5 star book.

Title: Treasure Island
Author: Robert Louis Stevenson
My Review:
first of all I just want to say I LISTENED to this book as a audiobook through Librivox.com
It was fun to listen to the book and I did it during some mindless work I had to do and walks.
One word of caution - if you're a re-reader like myself, beware. the narrater's voice and pace will stick with you afterwords.

And now to the book itself. It was fun in an adventury kind of way.
"excitement, thrills and wild wild adventures in the world of pirates!" is how I would describe it. However, it is rather childish, and the charachters are a bit too obvious and shallow in a way...
The good guys are very goody-fair-honest..., the bad guys are very drunk-lyers-conniving-stupid...
and you sort of know everything is going to work out for the best so the "cliff hangers" aren't very thrilling.

I think it would have been much much better if I listened to it on a weekly or even daily chapter basis, rather than chomping it down in 8 or so hours over 2-3 days...

Oh, and the language is a joy.

Enjoy!

Title: קהלת: הפילוסוף המקראי
Author: Haim Shapira
My Review:
Fascinating outlook on a very difficult biblical text. Bringing together philosophers from all over the world and history to answer the authors questions regarding the text, and his own attempt in understanding "Kohelet"'s thoughts and meanings at the writing of the text.

My only major criticism; there is a lot of philosophy from Tolstoy - even more that that of "Kohelet" in my opinion. Which makes the subject ("Kohelet") fade away a bit. Also I personally would've loved to get a bit more of the history and setting during the writing of the text (so I went to "Melachim" to find it...).

Loved the part about Job.

Title: Cat's Cradle
Author: Kurt Vonnegut Jr.
My Review:
Great clever book for anyone who likes Vonnegut.

Sharp wit, simple writing, that queasy "something's off" feeling throughout, and a very interesting and funny philosophy behind it all.

Short and enjoyable - perfect for a long weekend

Title: The Light Fantastic (Discworld, #2)

My Review:
This is a fun, fast paced, quick witted book.
The story really isn't its strong point - and I never really figured out the reason the heroes have gotten into the entire mess, but the little details, the side jokes and the background is great.

Just like any other discworld book, I won't say it changed my life in any way, except it was a fun week and I'll remember a couple of quotes (“Of course I'm sane, when trees start talking to me, I don't talk back.”, "crunch of chitin")

Title: Stoner
Author: John  Williams
My Review:
This is a very well written book. it tells the tale of proffessor William Stoner in a very touching, close up on an average, simple life.
With its slight twists, turns and its historic background it reads very fluently.
Every few pages some philosophy is thrown in, psychology too. I've found it very thought provoking - especially because it has no "fireworks". Everything feels very low-key, clever and sophisticated. It doesn't encourage you to turn the page - its your call, and yet you choose to turn it every time.

Very recommended to everyone who enjoys language.

Title: The Picture of Dorian Gray
Author: Oscar Wilde
My Review:
This book had me on the edge of my seat through most of it.
It's quite a compelling read, peppered with great suspense for no apparent reason.
The book had several main atractions which "bought" it's 4 star rating for me:
A. The philosophical question posed in it: Would you exchange youth and full atonement for your sins in society forever?
B. While there is very little graphic violence in 90% of the book, it keeps you almost scared of what will happen every time Dorian faces up to his portrait or his sins.
C. The Language is superb, written to flow out so cleanly and pretenutesly that you really have to applaud the writer.

So why not 5?
Because there was too much no-advancement ravings in the book.
I think Wilde just had a lot to say about life and tried to stick it all in this novel, even if it didn't really fit.

Title: Man's Search for Meaning: An Introduction to Logotherapy
Author: Viktor E. Frankl
My Review:
This book isn't so much about Logotherapy, it's mostly about history. Specifically it's about understanding day-to-day life in a concentration camp.
Being both Israeli and a direct descendant of a holocaust survivor, I know quite a lot about the subject. I've been to Auschwitz and Birkenau and all over Poland, I've studied the subject in school and in my spare time. So this book simply didn't shock or amaze me.

The first and larger part of the book is basically about Victor Frankel's view of life in several concentration and work camps. Being a psychiatrist, Frankel has a "cold" and clinical way of looking at things. The stories and conclusions are very interesting, shocking, hard to understand and thought provoking - to those who experience them for the first time.

The second part of the book (which is much shorter and more instructional) discusses Logotherapy, which is a school of psychiatry using goals and wishes to motivate and give meaning to life.

Overall this book probably deserves between 3 and 4 stars. I heard of many people who were "changed" by it, but I already know all the stories and horrors of the Holocaust, so it just didn't "do" it to me.

Title: Mostly Harmless (Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy, #5)
Author: Douglas Adams
My Review:
The last of the Hitchhiker's "Trilogy"... ahh what a series.
I'm a huge fan of the series and of Douglas Adams in general and have read the whole thing (all 5 books) when I started highschool. I always remembered this book as being diapointing, not funny and generally very sad and unworthy.

Re-reading it today (7 years later) I can say that it's really a great book.
It really is a bit darker and deeper than the rest of the series. The jokes are still there and the humour is sharp and satirical as always. There are a couple of extra edges to this book.
First, the matter of science (this applies to all D.A books, but this one especially) is a major theme and is as always explained in simple, funny and clever ways (reverse temporal engineering, multi-dimensional perceptions, sandwich making...)
Second, Adams seemed to have finally captured real emotion and behavour. This for me has always been the trouble with these books. I really don't want to spoil too much, but there are some very understandable feelings of loss, despair, loneliness, worry and feeling not-in-the-right-place that are really very well written, moving and relateable.

Overall, this is a strong finish to a great series. All the knots are nicely tied in the end, the quality hasn't diminished too much from the first book and the style, as always, is excellent.

I can't give it a 5 because I'm saving those for really special books, so 4 well deserved stars for this one.

Title: Making History
Author: Stephen Fry
My Review:
Great book.
Even though it is the longest book I read in a while (500+ pages), I got through it in a daze.

I'm having a hard time placing it, either as sci-fi, pure humor or just something else.
Surely anyone who likes the likes of Douglas Adams or other stuff by Fry will enjoy this book.

The language (as always with Fry) is very sculpted and sophisticated, at the same time remaining very believable and real.
The main character is very real and nice and I think anyone can somewhat relate to it.
Overall, the story is a bit far-fetched and weird but with Fry clever use of language and story-telling you sort of take it all in, only slightly questioning the credibility of it all.

The only real problem with this book is that some parts of it are written in script-write, which is uncomfortable on the eyes and makes those chapter a bit long, but then, that's artistic freedom for you.

Rereading my review I see that it is useless, however, that's how I feel so there... I would recommend it first and foremost to anyone who enjoyed the Liar, and then to everyone else who likes British humorous books
Enjoy
